block.p: Amanda Pedersen Williams and DeAndre William Calhoun were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Luis Leon, an Episcopal priest, at Washington National Cathedral. The Rev. Dr. James Stewart, a Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

Mrs. Calhoun, 26, is completing a combined degree program at Emory University as a candidate for an M.D. and a Ph.D. in public health. She is a Woodruff fellow and the Thomas Sellers fellow at Emory. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. Her parents, Karen Hastie Williams and Wesley S. Williams Jr., both lawyers, live in Washington. Her father is a partner in Covington & Burling, and her mother is a partner in Crowel & Moring. Mr. Williams is also the deputy chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond and a chairman of the Lockhart Group, a real estate, financial services, insurance, Internet and media group based in St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands and in Washington. Mrs. Williams is the chairwoman of the Black Student Fund, which recruits and refers black children from the Washington area to the top independent schools there.

Amanda Pedersen Williams and DeAndre William Calhoun were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Luis Leon, an Episcopal priest, at Washington National Cathedral. The Rev. Dr. James Stewart, a Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

Mrs. Calhoun, 26, is completing a combined degree program at Emory University as a candidate for an M.D. and a Ph.D. in public health. She is a Woodruff fellow and the Thomas Sellers fellow at Emory. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. Her parents, Karen Hastie Williams and Wesley S. Williams Jr., both lawyers, live in Washington. Her father is a partner in Covington & Burling, and her mother is a partner in Crowel & Moring. Mr. Williams is also the deputy chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond and a chairman of the Lockhart Group, a real estate, financial services, insurance, Internet and media group based in St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands and in Washington. Mrs. Williams is the chairwoman of the Black Student Fund, which recruits and refers black children from the Washington area to the top independent schools there.

The bride's grandfathers were Chief Judge William H. Hastie of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, the first African-American appointed to a federal Court of Appeals, and Wesley S. Williams Sr., the first African-American president of the District of Columbia Board of Education.

Mr. Calhoun, 28, is a mathematics teacher and upper school grade adviser at the Westminster Schools, a private school in Atlanta. He graduated cum laude from Morehouse College and received a master's degree in education from the University of Georgia. He is a son of Clarice Rodgers of Vallejo, Calif., and Roger Calhoun of Berkeley, Calif. His mother retired as a prekindergarten teacher at the Hopkins Montessori Child Development Center in Berkeley. His father, also retired, was a construction worker in the San Francisco area.
